awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Experiences in the Internet of Things
awd_abstract_narration:
This CISE Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site award funds a new REU site focused on the Internet of Things (IoT) at the University of Central Florida.  The REU site will provide 10 undergraduates per summer the opportunity to work with faculty mentors in state-of-the-art research labs on projects in the rapidly emerging area of IoT.  The Internet of Things is a new are of research characterized by tight integration between the physical components, software, wireless networking as well as the social context in which the devices operate.  The University of Central Florida has made significant investments in two centers, one institute, and a research cluster to explore research applications related to the IoT and cybersecurity.  In addition to conducting research the students will participate in other professional development activities such as industry field trips, professional ethics seminars, speakers and career guidance, and graduate school preparation.  An external evaluator will measure the success of the site and the impact on the students.  The culminating event of the summer will be a symposium where the students present their research results in a professional setting.

The is project is led by an outstanding team offering state-of-the art facilities and professional mentors to guide undergraduates in explorations of problems related to the Internet of Things. The goal of the site is to use the fast-moving IoT field to excite undergraduates and to provide research experiences to students who might not otherwise have opportunities for research experiences at their own institutions.  The IoT provides the basis for new consumer products such as smart phones, health and fitness tracking devices, accident avoidance technologies for vehicles, and home automation.  These are all areas which should appeal to students and actively engage them in projects that are meaningful to them and relevant to all citizens.  The students will participate in research and professional development activities all designed to achieve the goals of retaining and graduating undergraduate students in computer science and engineering, recruiting students from groups traditionally under-represented in computing fields, and increasing recruitment of students into graduate programs.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the REU Site: Research Experiences on the Internet of Things (IoT) at the University of Central Florida (UCF) is to train undergraduate students in research-based theory and applications of the technologies used in this fast-moving interdisciplinary field. The REU IoT site is an interdisciplinary partnership spanning three departments, one institute, and one college at UCF (Computer Science, Electrical & Computer Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Institute of Simulation and Training, and the College of Nursing.) The REU students joined well-established research groups under the close supervision of faculty with expertise in security, privacy, hardware design, data analytics, healthcare simulations, and social computing. The three objectives of this REU Site program were to i) recruit a diverse, talented pool of undergraduate students around the nation; ii) engage 10 students per year in an intensive 10-week summer experience; and iii) prepare students to transition to the workforce or graduate school.

The REU site has three major phases: (i) Exploration Phase (week 1); (ii) Immersion/Research Phase (weeks 2- 8); and (iii) Discover/Achievement Phase (weeks 9-10). The student activities included (i) socials to build a sense of community; (ii) weekly group discussions where REU students gave informal presentations on the progress of their projects; (iii) workshops on literature research, ethics of conducting research, and ethics on big data; (iv) industry panel discussion on career opportunities; and (v) seminars on graduate school preparation. The culminating event was the Symposium where students presented their research projects in a professional setting.

A total of 30 students were recruited over a three-year period of the grant (2016-2018). One (3%) was a freshman, 47% were sophomores, 30% were juniors, and 20% were seniors at the time of application. The participants represented a diverse pool: 50% women, 10% Hispanic, 13% African American, 3% biracial, 27% First Generation College student, and 3% had a documented disability. More than half (53%) of the students were from institutions with limited STEM research opportunities for undergraduates, and more than three-quarters (83%) were from institutions external to the host institution. Eighty-seven percent of students have graduated with their bachelor’s degree. Of those who have graduated, 92% have continued to graduate school and/or have been employed. Forty-three percent of students have authored or coauthored 10 journal papers/conference proceedings/book chapter and/or given 9 poster presentations at venues external to the REU program. REU staff have published 3 conference proceedings and 1 journal paper related to the REU program.
